docs.snippet: Back in the old days, a sign that a corporation had hit the big time was when it got a single-letter stock symbol on the New York Stock Exchange. For example, Ford has ''F,'' AT&T has ''T'' (for telephone) and United States Steel has ''X.''     On...
docs.lead_paragraph: Back in the old days, a sign that a corporation had hit the big time was when it got a single-letter stock symbol on the New York Stock Exchange. For example, Ford has ''F,'' AT&T has ''T'' (for telephone) and United States Steel has ''X.'' On the Web, there's another way a single letter can enhance a company's prestige. Go to Google's home page or browser toolbar and type a single letter into the search box. The search engine will then drop down a list of suggestions, based on overall search activity. There are 26 sites that have the distinction of being Google's first suggestion for each letter of the alphabet.

headline.main: A Is for Amazon, B Is for Best Buy . . .

docs.abstract: Names of 26 titans of Internet era have distinction of popping up as first suggestion when single letter is entered in Google search, beginning with A for Amazon; list of companies; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: By the measures of the movie rental market, YouTube's first foray into charging users to stream full-length feature films was hardly a runaway success. YouTube said last month that it would dip its toe into the digital movie rental business with five independent films tied to the Sundance Film Festival. The company said the five films, which were available for 10 days, received a combined 2,684 views.

headline.main: YouTube's Entry Into Film Rentals

docs.lead_paragraph: The police in central China have arrested three people and seized money and equipment worth hundreds of thousands of dollars in a crackdown on the country's biggest commercial operation to train computer hackers, state media reported Sunday and Monday. But Western specialists in cybersecurity were skeptical that the arrests signified any broad commitment by China to halt the assaults on computer security that Google and other Western companies have endured in recent months.

headline.main: China Announces 3 Arrests in a Crackdown on Hacking

docs.abstract: Police in Hubei Province in central China arrest three people and seize equipment in crackdown on country's biggest commercial operation to train computer hackers; Western specialists in cybersecurity are dismissive of move, noting that servers that have been used in attacks on Google and other Western companies' networks are not shut down (M)

This one has a few thousand fans, a modest but respectable number considering this: Who wants to be a fan of snowmaggedon?The word could be the most annoying new portmanteau to be widely adopted by the mainstream media. Watch out, staycation, snowmaggedon is a trending topic for the New York area on Twitter (#snowmaggedon) and has already appeared in the first few paragraphs of Wikipedia's entry on Armageddon, to wit:

docs.snippet: Look at the comments on the Amazon and Barnes & Noble Web sites if you want to know how some readers feel about the price of an e-book. The readers are used to $9.99, the price Amazon set when it introduced Kindle, and when they see an e-book cost...
docs.lead_paragraph: Look at the comments on the Amazon and Barnes & Noble Web sites if you want to know how some readers feel about the price of an e-book. The readers are used to $9.99, the price Amazon set when it introduced Kindle, and when they see an e-book costing more, or when an e-book's release is delayed while the far more expensive hardcover grabs up buyers -- well, you could fill a book with the grumbling. Readers are latecomers to the battle over digital price. Until recently, publishers and retailers have hashed it out, with publishers generally worried that $9.99 -- not a magic number but the one that managed to hook digital readers -- devalued books in readers' minds. Publishers gained back ground when Apple and Google indicated they were open to higher prices. Readers may have the last word.

headline.main: Bash This Book

docs.abstract: Tim Bower drawing illustrates scornful reaction by customers to prices of electronic books; readers who are used to paying $9.99, price Amazon charged when it introduced Kindle, tend to grumble when they are charged more

docs.snippet: Google and Mountain View are remaking the old company-town template, giving it an information-age accent. This and other highlights from Friday's Bay Area Report....
docs.lead_paragraph: Googleplex, the City | As Silicon Valley companies grew, they tended to stay within their own clean campuses, with the cities around them little more than an incidental item on their stationery. But it is different with Google and Mountain View, where the search-engine giant is recreating the 19th-century company town with a 21st-century accent. The union has produced the same mix of plans, dreams and frustration, of civic-corporate boosterism and local concern about the giant in their midst that Henry Ford might have found familiar. For Google, Mountain View is part home and part beta-testing ground. For the city, Google is part economic engine, part benefactor and a soon-to-be real-estate developer with an opportunistic eye for underused assets - like the landing strip at Moffett Field, where jets of Google executives now come and go.

headline.main: Google Programs Company Town 2.0 and Highlights From Friday's Bay Area Report

docs.abstract: Google and Mountain View are remaking the old company-town template, giving it an information-age accent. This and other highlights from Friday's Bay Area Report.

docs.snippet: Lesson Plan | Developing Internet search strategies by trial and error, and telling the stories of these searches to benefit other Web users and researchers....
docs.lead_paragraph: Overview | Do Internet search engines point us to the information that we need or confuse us with irrelevant or questionable information? How can Internet users improve their searches to find reliable information? What are some ways to perform effective searches? In this lesson, students conduct Web searches on open-ended questions, and draw on their experiences to develop guides to searching effectively and finding reliable information online.

headline.main: Just Google It? Developing Internet Search Skills

docs.snippet: Watching and surfing, surfing and watching: a substantial number of viewers who tuned in to the opening ceremony for the Olympic Winter Games on Feb. 12 spent time on their computers, too. According to Nielsen, 13 percent of viewers went online du...
docs.lead_paragraph: Watching and surfing, surfing and watching: a substantial number of viewers who tuned in to the opening ceremony for the Olympic Winter Games on Feb. 12 spent time on their computers, too. According to Nielsen, 13 percent of viewers went online during the four-hour event on NBC. Facebook had the largest share, followed by Google, Yahoo, AOL and MSN, obvious sources of search, e-mail and news. The broadcast viewers who went online each browsed for an average of 32 minutes. SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline.main: Popular Demand

docs.abstract: Chart of top 10 online domains surfed by TV viewers of Olympic Winter Games on Feb 12; photo (S)

docs.snippet: Our Friday morning roundup of technology news also looks at 3-D movies and televisions and the poor sales at Palm....
docs.lead_paragraph: Facebook Granted Patent on the News FeedAs we noted Thursday, Facebook has been granted a patent for the its central feature, the news feed. ReadWriteWeb spotlights the discussion in the blogosphere on the topic, with many questioning if Facebook actually invented the algorithm-driven newsfeed. Bloggers also ask if the company will enforce its patent against other services, including Google Reader and Google Buzz, or if the move is just defensive.

headline.main: Bits Scan: Facebook's Patent, Nokia's Woes and Phishing on Twitter
